4 - Sciatic nerve - The nerve passes over the obturator internus, gemellus superior, gemellus inferior and quadratus femoris. It supplies knee flexors and muscles below the knee. Paralysis of this nerve results in flail foot and severe difficulty in walking.
subject: Anatomy

question_text: A 50-year-old woman underwent total hip replacement surgery. During the procedure, the surgeon accidentally severed a nerve. Post-operatively, the patient had a gluteus maximus lurch and wasting of the muscle. Which of the following nerves is likely to be injured?
explanation:
In the given clinical scenario, the inferior gluteal nerve is likely to be injured.
The gluteus maximus is innervated by the inferior gluteal nerve. Injury to the nerve causes atrophy of the muscle causing weakness in the extension of the thigh. The patients typically have a gluteus maximus lurch.
The gluteus maximus may be tested by extension of the hip against resistance, in the supine or prone position.
subject: Anatomy

question_text: What is the action of the muscle at the hip, which is attached to the marked area in the image below.
explanation:
The image shows the posterior surface of the femur, and the structure marked is gluteal tuberosity, to which the gluteus maximus muscle is attached. It causes extension and lateral rotation at the hip joint.
The femur can be divided into:
The proximal femur - Consists of the head, neck, greater and lesser trochanters. The intertrochanteric line is present on the anterior surface at the junction of the neck and shaft of the femur while the intertrochanteric crest is present on the posterior surface.
The shaft of the femur - Consists of linea aspera (bony crest present on the posterior surface), gluteal tuberosity, and pectineal line
The distal femur - Consists of the medial condyle, lateral condyle, intercondylar fossa, and patellar surface
The image below shows attachments of various muscles over the posterior surface of the right femur.
Gluteus maximus muscle:
Origin:
Posterior aspect of the dorsal ilium, posterior to the posterior gluteal line
Posterior superior iliac spine
Posterior aspect of sacrum and coccyx
Sacrotuberous ligament.
Insertion - It is inserted mainly in fascia lata at the iliotibial band and also into the gluteal tuberosity on the posterior femoral surface.
Action:
Major extensor of the hip joint
Lateral rotation of the hip joint
Active in powerful abduction of the thigh
Arterial Supply - Inferior and superior gluteal arteries and the first perforating branch of the profunda femoris artery.
Nerve Supply- Inferior gluteal nerve (L5, S1 and S2).
subject: Anatomy

question_text: Which of the following muscles is attached to the lateral surface of the greater trochanter?
explanation:
The gluteus medius muscle is attached to the lateral surface of the greater trochanter.
Greater trochanter: It is a large and quadrangular projection arising from the junction of the neck and shaft of the femur. Muscles inserted into it are -
Gluteus minimus
Gluteus medius
Piriformis
Common tendon of obturator internus and gamelli.
Lesser trochanter: It is a conical projection of the shaft present posteromedially. Muscles inserted to it are iliacus and psoas major
Surface marking: Greater trochanter lies inferior to the midpoint of the iliac crest and at the level of the horizontal plane passing through the pubic tubercle.
subject: Anatomy

question_text: Iliotibial tract receives the insertion of which of the following muscles?
explanation:
The iliotibial tract receives the insertion of tensor fasciae latae.
The iliotibial tract is the modification of the deep fascia of the thigh. The proximal end gives attachment to the tensor fascia lata and gluteus maximus. The distal end is attached to Gerdy’s tubercle present on the lateral condyle of the tibia.
subject: Anatomy

question_text: Which of the following muscles is a powerful abductor of hip joint?
explanation:
The powerful abductor of hip joint is the gluteus medius. Abduction is assisted by the following muscles:
Gluteus minimus
Tensor fascia lata
Piriformis
Sartorius
Adduction of the hip joint is mainly caused by
Adductor longus
Adductor brevis
Adductor magnus
Gracilis
Flexion of the hip joint is caused by:
Psoas major
Iliacus
Rectus femoris
Assisted by:
Pectineus
Tensor fascia lata
Sartorius
Extension of the hip joint is caused by:
Gluteus maximus
Biceps femoris
Semitendinosus
Semimembranosus (hamstrings)
Adductor magnus
Assisted by - posterior fibers of gluteus medius
subject: Anatomy

question_text: Which of the following muscles causes external rotation of the hip joint?
explanation:
The external rotation of the hip joint is caused by the following muscles:
Gluteus maximus
Obturator internus
Superior and inferior gemelli
Quadratus femoris
Piriformis
Assisted by
Obturator externus
Sartorius
Internal rotation of the hip joint is caused by the following muscles:
Gluteus medius
Gluteus minimus
Tensor fascia lata
Adductor muscles
subject: Anatomy

question_text: The posterior femoral muscles are innervated by which nerve?
explanation:
The posterior femoral muscles (hamstring muscles) are innervated by the sciatic nerve.
Semitendinosus, semimembranosus, and the long head of biceps femoris are innervated by tibia division of the sciatic nerve (L5, S1, and S2)
The short head of biceps femoris is innervated by the common peroneal division of the sciatic nerve.
subject: Anatomy

question_text: All of the the following muscles are attached to the ischial tuberosity except:
explanation:
The short head of the biceps femoris is not attached to the ischial tuberosity. It is attached to the lateral lip of the linea aspera, lateral supracondylar ridge of the femur, and the lateral intermuscular septum of the thigh.
The ischial tuberosity is broadly divided into upper and lower areas:
The upper area is further subdivided into a superolateral part for the semimembranosus and an inferomedial part for the long head of the biceps femoris and the semitendinosus.
The lower area is subdivided by an irregular vertical ridge, into lateral and medial areas. The arger lateral area is for the adductor magnus. The smaller medial area is covered by adipose tissue, which usually contains the sciatic bursa of the gluteus maximus, which supports the body in sitting.
subject: Anatomy

question_text: A 40-year-old woman presented with severe pain in the buttocks extending down the back of the right leg. MRI revealed inflammation of the piriformis muscle. Entrapment of which of the following nerves is likely to cause the given condition?
explanation:
The clinical features are suggestive of piriformis syndrome, which occurs due to the entrapment of the sciatic nerve.
It is triggered by sitting for a long time or running, climbing stairs, or applying firm pressure directly over the piriformis muscle. Early signs include pain, tingling, or numbness in the buttocks. Later it may lead to severe pain extending down the length of the sciatic nerve.
subject: Anatomy

question_text: An Indian fast bowler suffered a hamstring injury while practicing due to which he was dropped out of the team. Which of the following muscle is not likely to be injured?
explanation:
The sartorius muscle is not a part of hamstring muscles.
Hamstring muscles are present in the posterior compartment of the thigh and include semimembranosus, semitendinosus, and biceps femoris.
They cause the flexion of the knee joint and extension of the hip joint. In addition to this, semimembranosus and semitendinosus cause medial rotation of the hip and knee joint, and biceps femoris causes lateral rotation of the hip and knee joint.
subject: Anatomy

question_text: Which of the following muscles is not a part of the anterior compartment of the thigh?
explanation:
The gracilis muscle belongs to the medial compartment of the thigh. Muscles of the anterior compartment:
Sartorius
Rectus femoris
Vasti medialis, lateralis, and intermedius
Articularis genus Note:
Adductor longus and pectineus are sometimes considered to be part of both the anterior and the medial compartments.
subject: Anatomy

question_text: A 30-year-old woman suddenly falls during her dance performance. She was rushed to the hospital by her friends. On examination her knee was swollen and her movements were restricted. On X-ray examination, lateral displacement of the patella was noted. The weakness of which of the following muscle is responsible for this condition?
explanation:
The weakness of the vastus medialis is responsible for the lateral displacement of the patella.
The lowest fibers of the vastus medialis muscle, which are attached medially to the upper half of the patella are referred to as vastus medialis obliquus. These fibers of the vastus medialis prevent the lateral displacement of the patella, during knee motion. The weakness of the vastus medialis obliquus may lead to patellar instability and pain.
subject: Anatomy

question_text: Which of the following muscles cause medial rotation of the flexed knee?
explanation:
Medial rotation of the flexed knee is produced by the following muscles:
Semimembranosus
Popliteus
Semitendinosus
Assisted by
Sartorius
Gracilis
Knee joint is a complex synovial joint consisting of tibiofemoral and patellofemoral articulations. Movements occurring at knee joint are flexion, extension, medial rotation, and lateral rotation.
Flexion - biceps femoris, semitendinosus, and semimembranosus (hamstrings)
Extension - quadriceps femoris, assisted by tensor fasciae latae
Medial rotation of the flexed leg - popliteus, semimembranosus, and semitendinosus
Lateral rotation of the flexed leg - biceps femoris
Note: Semimembranosus tendinopathy may develop as a result of the overuse of muscle usually cyclists and marathon runners. Patients may complain of insidious pain in the posteromedial part of the knee radiating distally to the medial calf or proximally to the posteromedial thigh. It is a cause of chronic knee pain that often goes undiagnosed as it is poorly understood.
subject: Anatomy

question_text:
A patient presents the OPD with complaints of acute pain and swelling over the dorsum of her right midfoot. On examination, tenderness was present and the resisted dorsiflexion test
for the great toe was positive. The muscle affected is innervated by which nerve?
explanation: In the given scenario, the muscle likely to be affected is extensor hallucis longus, which is innervated by the deep peroneal nerve.
subject: Anatomy

question_text: The anterior compartment of the leg contains all of the following muscles except:
explanation:
Peroneus brevis muscle belongs to the lateral compartment of the leg.
Muscles of the anterior compartment of the leg produce dorsiflexion (extension) of the ankle. They are:
Extensor digitorum longus
Extensor hallucis longus
Tibialis anterior
Peroneus tertius (inverts and everts foot)
Muscles of the posterior compartment produce plantar flexion. They include superficial and deep groups which are separated by the transverse intermuscular septum.
The superficial flexor group consists of the gastrocnemius, plantaris, and soleus.
The deep flexor group consists of popliteus, flexor digitorum longus, flexor hallucis longus, and tibialis posterior.
Muscles of lateral compartment evert the ankle and include peroneus longus and peroneus brevis.
subject: Anatomy

question_text: Which muscle is not involved in the inversion of foot?
explanation:
Peroneus longus muscle is not involved in the inversion of the foot. It causes eversion and plantar flexion.
Inversion of the foot is a movement in which the medial border of the foot is elevated so that the sole faces medially.
Tibialis anterior - Causes dorsiflexion and inversion of the foot
Tibialis posterior - Causes plantar flexion and inversion of the foot
Extensor hallucis longus - Causes extension of the great toe, dorsiflexion of the foot, and inversion of the foot (minimal action)
Eversion of the foot is a movement where the lateral border of the foot is elevated so that the sole faces laterally. Peroneus longus, peroneus brevis, and peroneus tertius are the muscles involved.
These movements take place, mainly at the talocalcaneal and the talocalcaneonavicular joints, and partly at the transverse tarsal joint.
subject: Anatomy

question_text: A patient with weakness of leg is not able to perform the movement shown in the image. Which muscle weakness causes loss of this movement?
explanation:
The action shown in the image is plantar flexion of the ankle joint and weakness of gastrocnemius muscle causes loss of this movement.
The plantar flexion of the toe is produced mainly by gastrocnemius and soleus, assisted by plantaris, tibialis posterior, flexor hallucis longus, and flexor digitorum longus.
Dorsiflexion is caused by the tibialis anterior and assisted by extensor digitorum longus, extensor hallucis longus, and peroneus tertius.
subject: Anatomy

question_text: Which of the following muscles is known as triceps surae?
explanation:
The gastrocnemius (two heads) and soleus muscles are collectively known as triceps surae. They constitute a powerful muscular mass whose main function is plantar flexion of the foot.
The main bulk of the calf is formed by gastrocnemius, plantaris, and soleus muscles. These 3 muscles form the superficial flexor group of the posterior compartment of the lower leg.
subject: Anatomy

question_text: Which of the following passive movements causes pain in a patient suffering from deep posterior compartment syndrome?
explanation:
Dorsiflexion of the foot causes pain in the deep posterior compartment syndrome of the leg.
All tibial fractures should be monitored for signs of compartment syndrome. Severe pain is the most important clinical feature. Regular clinical evaluation is important because swelling, blistering, and skin necrosis is associated with late, severe compartment syndrome.
Compartment syndromes of the lower limb:
Superficial and deep posterior compartment syndrome - There will be pain on passive dorsiflexion of the foot and on the toe extension
Anterior compartment syndrome - There will be pain on passive plantar flexion of the foot and toe flexion
Lateral compartment syndrome - There will be pain on passive foot inversion.
subject: Anatomy

question_text:
The first layer of the sole consists of:
Abductor hallucis
explanation:
The first layer of the sole consists of abductor hallucis.
The muscles of the sole of the foot are arranged in 4 layers. From superficial to deep, the layers are numbered from one to four.
Muscles of the sole of the foot are:
1st layer: This is the superficial layer which includes abductor hallucis, abductor digiti minimi, and flexor digitorum brevis.
2nd layer: It consists of flexor accessorius and the four lumbrical muscles,the tendons of flexor hallucis longus and flexor digitorum longus run in the same plane as the muscles of the second layer.
3rd layer: It contains the shorter intrinsic muscles of the toes, which are flexor hallucis brevis, adductor hallucis and flexor digiti minimi brevis.
4th layer: It consists of plantar and dorsal interossei and the tendons of tibialis posterior and fibularis longus.
Nerves & Vessels of Lower Limb
subject: Anatomy

question_text: Which of the following nerve is a branch of lumbar plexus?
explanation:
The femoral nerve is a branch of the lumbar plexus and arises from the posterior (dorsal)
divisions of the ventral rami of L2–L4.
The sciatic nerve, posterior femoral cutaneous nerve, and nerve to obturator internus are a part of sacral plexus.
subject: Anatomy

question_text: A patient presents with tingling, numbness, and burning pain in the outer part of the right thigh. There is no motor dysfunction. What is the root value of this patient's affected nerve?
explanation:
The given scenario is suggestive of meralgia paresthetica, in which the lateral cutaneous nerve of the thigh is affected. The root value of this nerve is L2 and L3.
It arises from the posterior divisions of the ventral rami of L2 and L3 and supplies the skin of the anterior and lateral surfaces of the thigh upto the knee.
The images given below represent the root value and the area supplied by the lateral cutaneous nerve of the thigh.
subject: Anatomy

question_text: Which of the following nerve is a branch of the sacral plexus?
explanation: The sciatic nerve is a branch of the sacral plexus. It is the largest branch of the sacral plexus.
subject: Anatomy

question_text: The femoral nerve is split into the anterior and posterior divisions by which of the following arteries?
explanation:
The femoral nerve is split into the anterior and posterior divisions by the lateral circumflex femoral artery.
The course of femoral nerve is given below:
Arises from posterior division of ventral rami of L2-L4 spinal segments on the posterior abdominal wa
Enters the femoral triangle by passing under the inguinal ligament
In the femoral triangle, it lies lateral to the femoral artery and outside the femoral sheath
Divided into anterior and posterior branches by lateral circumflex femoral artery
Note: Obturator nerve is divided into anterior and posterior divisions by obturator externus in the upper part and adductor brevis in the lower part.
subject: Anatomy

question_text: Which of the following branches of the femoral nerve arises from its main trunk and passes below the inguinal ligament?
explanation:
The Nerve to pectineus arises near and passes below the inguinal ligament and then runs behind the femoral sheath.
The femoral nerve gives off the nerve to iliacus and pectineus before it divides into the anterior and posterior divisions.
The image given below shows the course of the femoral nerve.
subject: Anatomy

question_text: A 60-year-old woman after a trivial fall presents with pelvic fracture along with left femoral nerve injury. The function of all of the following muscles will be affected except:
explanation:
Gracilis is supplied by the obturator nerve and not the femoral nerve. Hence, the function of gracilis muscle will be normal in this patient.
Branches of the femoral nerve:
Before entering the thigh, the femoral nerve supplies branches to the iliacus and pectineus muscles
The anterior division of femoral nerves supplies the sartorius and gives sensation to
the anteromedial aspect of the thigh by the branches medial cutaneous nerve of the thigh and intermediate cutaneous nerve of the thigh
The posterior division of the femoral nerve supplies branches to the quadriceps femoris muscles, knee joint and gives sensation to the medial aspect of the leg by the saphenous nerve.
The image given below shows the course of the femoral nerve.
subject: Anatomy

question_text: A patient presents with a loss of extension of the knee joint. On examination, decreased sensation over the anterior aspect of the thigh is noted. Which of the following nerve is likely damaged in this patient?
explanation:
Loss of extension of the knee joint with decreased sensation over the anterior aspect of the thigh suggests damage to the femoral nerve.
The femoral nerve innervates the quadriceps femoris muscles which are the extensors of the knee joint. It provides sensory branches to the anterior and medial aspect of the thigh by medial and intermediate cutaneous nerves of the thigh.
The image given below shows the course of the femoral nerve.
subject: Anatomy

question_text: In a patient, following venous cut down for access to the great saphenous vein, sensation over the medial side of the leg was lost. The affected nerve is a branch of which of the following nerves?
explanation:
Loss of sensation of the medial side of the leg denotes injury to the saphenous nerve. It is a branch of the posterior division of the femoral nerve.
The saphenous nerve is the largest cutaneous branch of the femoral nerve.
It arises from the posterior division of the femoral nerve. In the femoral triangle, it lies lateral to the femoral artery. It then enters the adductor canal where it crosses anterior to the femoral artery to lie medial to it. It leaves the adductor canal by piercing the fascia lata between the gracilis and sartorius and supplies the skin over the patella.
It then descends along the medial border of the tibia along with the long saphenous vein and supplies the skin on the medial side of the knee leg and foot as far as up to the first metatarsophalangeal joint.
The images given below show the cutaneous innervation of the lower limb.
subject: Anatomy

question_text: Obturator nerve block is performed on a patient with severe chronic hip pain. Anterior division of this nerve innervates all of the following muscles except:
explanation:
The anterior division of the obturator nerve does not innervate the adductor magnus. It is supplied by the posterior division of the obturator nerve.
The obturator nerve arises from the anterior division of the ventral rami of L2-L4. Near the obturator foramen, it divides into anterior and posterior branches.
Anterior division supplies pectineus, adductor longus, adductor brevis, and gracilis
Posterior division supplies adductor magnus, obturator externus. It also supplies adductor brevis if the muscle is not supplied by the anterior division
The image given below shows the course of the obturator nerve.
subject: Anatomy

question_text: Which of the following nerve does not innervate the muscles of the gluteal region?
explanation:
The sciatic nerve does not innervate the muscles of the gluteal region.
It is the largest nerve of the body and is made up of L4 to S3 spinal nerves of the sacral plexus. It leaves the pelvis through the greater sciatic foramen, inferior to the piriformis. It descends in the posterior thigh and divides into the tibial and common peroneal nerves proximal to the knee joint.
The tibial component of the sciatic nerve supplies:
Semimembranosus
Semitendinosus
Ischial part of adductor magnus
Long head of biceps femoris
The common fibular component of the sciatic nerve supplies a short head of the biceps femoris. The images given below shows the course of the Sciatic nerve.
subject: Anatomy

question_text: A 40-year-old man comes with a history of a hip fracture which was treated surgically, four months ago. You observe him walking with the gait shown below. Injury to which of the following nerves is most likely in this patient?
explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of left superior gluteal nerve injury.
The patient shows characteristic lurching gait/ Trendelenburg's gait (positive Trendelenburg's sign), which is seen in paralysis of gluteus medius and gluteus minimus muscles. These muscles are supplied by the superior gluteal nerve.
When the leg on one side is lifted off the ground, the gluteus medius and minimus muscles, on the opposite supported side, exert traction on the hip bone by acting from the femur. This action results in the slight raising of the pelvis on the unsupported side, which helps maintain the trunk in the upright position.
When the gluteus medius and minimus are paralyzed, the pelvis sinks down on the unsupported
(normal) side, when the patient tries to stand on the affected limb.
In the given case, when the patient lifts up his right leg and tries to stand on the left leg, his right pelvis tilts down. This shows that the left side abduction mechanism is paralyzed and the right side is normal. Hence, the left superior gluteal nerve injury is present in this case.
The image given below shows the Trendelenberg test.
Note: Inferior gluteal nerve supplies the gluteus maximus muscle.
subject: Anatomy

question_text: Foot drop is caused by damage to:
explanation:
Foot drop is caused by damage to the common peroneal nerve.
The common peroneal nerve is a component of the sciatic nerve. In the posterior thigh, it supplies the short head of the biceps femoris. It curves around the neck of the fibula deep to peroneus longus and divides into superficial and deep peroneal nerves.
The superficial peroneal nerve innervates peroneus longus and peroneus brevis which are the evertors of the foot and to the skin over the dorsal area of the foot except for the first webspace and lateral side of the little toe.
The deep peroneal nerve innervates all muscles of the anterior compartment which are the dorsiflexors of the foot, extensor digitorum brevis, first two dorsal interossei muscles, and skin between great and second toes.
Hence, injury to the common peroneal nerve will lead to:
Weakness of dorsiflexion of foot or foot drop
Loss of eversion
Loss of extension of toes
Sensory loss
Anterior and lateral side of the leg
Dorsum of the foot including the medial side of the great toe
Th image given below shows the course of common peroneal nerve.
subject: Anatomy

question_text: A 45-year-old man came for his cast removal after a right tibial fracture. You noted that the patient lifted his right leg high to take a step. On examination, the right foot was inverted and sensory loss was present on the whole dorsum of the right foot. Which of the following nerves is most likely affected in this patient?
explanation:
The nerve affected in this patient is the common fibular nerve (common peroneal nerve). It is derived from the dorsal branches of the L4 - L5 and S1 - S2 ventral rami.
The sciatic nerve divides into the tibial nerve and the common fibular nerve.
The common fibular nerve runs obliquely along the lateral side of the popliteal fossa to the fibular head. It lies between the biceps femoris and lateral head of the gastrocnemius. It then curves laterally around the neck of the fibula, where it is most commonly injured (e.g., due to a tight plaster cast).
It gets divided into superficial and deep fibular nerves. Injury to the common peroneal nerve will lead to:
Weakness of dorsiflexion of foot or foot drop
Loss of eversion
Loss of extension of toes
Sensory loss
Anterior and lateral side of the leg
Dorsum of the foot including the medial side of the great toe
The images given below show the common peroneal nerve course and the sensory area supplied.
Note: Ankle reflex is preserved in common peroneal nerve palsy.
subject: Anatomy

question_text: Which of the following does not share its nerve supply with the rest of the given muscles?
explanation:
Peroneus longus is innervated by the superficial peroneal nerve. The rest of the muscles mentioned above are innervated by the deep peroneal nerve.
The anterior compartment of the leg is supplied by the deep peroneal nerve. It consists of:
Tibialis anterior
Extensor hallucis longus
Extensor digitorum longus
Peroneus tertius
The lateral compartment of leg is supplied by the superficial peroneal nerve. It consists of peroneus longus and peroneus brevis.
The posterior compartment of leg is supplied by the tibial nerve. It consists of
Gastrocnemius
Soleus
Plantaris
Popliteus
Flexor hallucis longus
Flexor digitorum longus
Tibialis posterior
subject: Anatomy

question_text: In a patient with Morton’s neuroma, branches of which of the following nerves will get entrapped?
explanation:
Morton’s neuroma may occur due to the entrapment of branches of the medial plantar nerve.
It is the most common form of nerve entrapment in the foot. It is due to the entrapment of the 3rd common digital nerve which is a branch of the medial plantar nerve.
The medial plantar nerve can also be compressed at the Knot of Henry. It is the point where the tendon of flexor hallucis longus passes deep to the tendon of flexor digitorum longus to reach the medial side of the sole of the foot.
The image given below shows the Morton's neuroma.
subject: Anatomy

question_text: Baxter’s nerve is a branch of which of the following nerves?
explanation:
Baxter’s nerve is a branch of the lateral plantar nerve.
Clinical significance: Compression of Baxter's nerve by the deep fascia that covers abductor hallucis is implicated to be a possible cause of chronic heel pain and plantar fasciitis.
subject: Anatomy

question_text: What is the root value of cremasteric reflex?
explanation:
Cremasteric reflex is mediated by L1 and L2. In this reflex, there is ipsilateral elevation of the testicle following stroking of the medial thigh.
The cremasteric reflex's afferent and efferent branches:
Afferent - Femoral branch of genitofemoral nerve
Efferent - Genital branch of genitofemoral nerve
Given below are the various reflexes with their root values.
subject: Anatomy

question_text: Which of the following is not a branch of the femoral artery?
explanation:
The deep circumflex iliac artery is a branch of the external iliac artery, not the femoral artery.
The femoral artery is the continuation of the external iliac artery. It starts behind the inguinal ligament midway between the anterior superior iliac spine and pubic symphysis.
It descends in the thigh anteromedially in the femoral triangle and passes through the adductor canal. It exits the adductor canal by passing through adductor hiatus, to reach the popliteal fossa and becomes the popliteal artery.
Branches of the femoral artery given below:
Superficial epigastric artery
Superficial circumflex iliac artery
Superficial external pudendal artery
Deep external pudendal arteries
Muscular branches
Profunda femoris artery
Descending genicular artery
subject: Anatomy

question_text: Which of the following artery does not take part in the cruciate anastomosis?
explanation:
The superior gluteal artery does not contribute to the formation of cruciate anastomosis.
Cruciate anastomosis lies at the level of the lesser trochanter and is formed by:
Transverse branches of medial and lateral circumflex femoral arteries
Descending branch of the inferior gluteal artery
Ascending branch of the first perforating artery
The image given below shows the anastomosis around the hip joint.
Note: Traumatic insults to the lower extremity (fractures, stab wounds, or gunshot wounds) can result in blood loss. It is important for the clinician to understand the arterial anastomoses in the affected area so that bleeding can be appropriately managed and exsanguination can be avoided.
subject: Anatomy

question_text: A 60-year-old man presented with pain while walking after a prolonged flight travel. U trasonography revealed thrombus in the short saphenous vein. If the thrombus gets dislodged, it is likely to enter which of the following veins first?
explanation:
A thrombus in the short saphenous vein may get dislodged and enter the popliteal vein. The embolus may further travel into the right heart and eventually may cause a pulmonary embolism.
The short saphenous vein is the continuation of the lateral side of the dorsal venous arch. It passes behind the lateral malleolus and drains into the popliteal vein in the popliteal fossa. The popliteal vein continues as the femoral vein proximal to the knee.
The image given below shows the venous drainage of the lower limb.
subject: Anatomy

question_text:
What are above knee perforators known as?
Dodd veins
explanation:
Above knee perforators are known as Dodd's veins.
Perforator veins connect the deep and superficial venous systems, allowing the passage of blood in between them. Following are the named perforators of the lower limb:
Proximal thigh level perforators - Hunter perforator veins
Distal thigh perforators - Dodd perforator veins
Below the knee perforators - Boyd perforator veins
Calf level perforators - Cockett perforator veins
Important Structures of Lower Limb
subject: Anatomy

question_text: Which of the following structures do not pass through both greater and lesser sciatic foramens?
explanation:
The tendon of the obturator internus muscle passes only through the lesser sciatic foramen. Structures passing through both the greater and lesser sciatic foramen:
Pudendal nerve
Internal pudendal vessels
Nerve to obturator internus.
subject: Anatomy

question_text: All of the following structures are derived from the aponeurosis of the external oblique muscle except:
explanation:
Linea semilunaris is derived from the aponeurosis of the internal oblique muscle.
Pectineal ligament, inguinal ligament and lacunar ligament are derived from the external oblique aponeurosis.
subject: Anatomy

question_text: Which of the following muscles does not form the floor of the femoral triangle?
explanation:
Psoas major forms the floor of the femoral triangle, not psoas minor.
The femoral triangle is an intermuscular space in the anteromedial aspect of the thigh. Its boundaries are:
Lateral boundary is formed by the medial margin of sartorius
Medial boundary is formed by the medial margin of adductor longus.
Floor of the femoral triangle from lateral to medial is formed by:
Iliacus
Psoas major
Pectineus
Adductor longus
subject: Anatomy

question_text: Which of the following forms the lateral boundary of the femoral triangle?
explanation: The lateral boundary of the femoral triangle is formed by the medial margin of the sartorius. Its medial boundary is formed by the medial margin of adductor longus.
subject: Anatomy

question_text: A resident was inserting a central venous line through the femoral vein. He accidentally injured the structure medial to the femoral vein, within the femoral sheath. Which structure is likely to be injured?
explanation:
The lymphatic vessels lie medial to the femoral vein and are likely to be injured in this case.
Femoral sheath is the funnel-shaped prolongation of the fascia which contains femoral vessels. Anteriorly it is made of transversalis fascia and posteriorly it is made of fascia iliaca.
It is divided into three compartments:
The lateral compartment contains femoral artery
The intermediate compartment contains femoral vein
The medial compartment which is termed as femoral canal contains:
Lymphatic vessels
Areolar tissue
Lymph node of Cloquet.
The empty space in the femoral canal allows distension of the adjacent femoral vein, so it can cope with increased venous return, or increased intra-abdominal pressure.
subject: Anatomy

question_text:
A patient underwent an aortic valve replacement surgery through the femoral artery.
Post-operatively, he complaints of groin pain radiating down the anteromedial thigh. Which of the following is true regarding the nerve injured?
options: It lies medial to the femoral artery
It is not a content of the femoral sheath
The nerve injured is the sciatic nerve
It arises from the anterior cords of the lumbar plexus
explanation:
The nerve injured is the femoral nerve. Femoral nerve is not a content of the femoral sheath.
Femoral sheath forms a fascial compartment which is further divided into 3 compartments by the intervening septae:
The lateral compartment contains femoral artery
The intermediate compartment contains femoral vein
The medial compartment which is termed as femoral canal contains
Lymphatic vessels
Areolar tissue
Lymph node of cloquet
The empty space in the femoral canal allows distension of the adjacent femoral vein, so it can cope with increased venous return, or increased intra-abdominal pressure.
Option A - Femoral nerve lies lateral to the femoral artery
Option C - Sciatic nerve injury may occur after misplaced intramuscular injection in the gluteal region. It leads to loss of sensation at the outer side of ankle and heel and foot drop.
subject: Anatomy

question_text: A middle aged man is found to have a globular swelling below and lateral to the pubic tubercle. A diagnosis of femoral hernia is made. Which structure forms the posterior border of the ring the hernia passes through?
explanation:
Femoral hernia will pass through the femoral ring proximally. The posterior border of the femoral ring is formed by the pectineal ligament.
Relations of the femoral ring:
Anterior border by the inguinal ligament
Posterior border by the
Pectineal ligament
Superior ramus of the pubic bone
Pectineus muscle
Medial border by the lacunar ligament
Lateral border by the femoral vein
subject: Anatomy

question_text: An adolescent is crossing the road while playing loud music on his headphones. He is struck by a car and rushed to the emergency room. The physicians notice a distal femur fracture with vascular compromise. Intraoperatively, the femoral vessels are found to be injured at the adductor hiatus. Which muscle is likely to be involved in this injury ?
explanation:
In the given scenario, femoral vessels are injured at the adductor hiatus. The adductor hiatus is an opening in the tendon of the adductor magnus. Hence, the muscle likely to be injured is the adductor magnus.
Clinical relevance: The adductor part of the adductor magnus attaches to the distal femur. Distal femur fractures may cause femoral artery injury and impairment of the blood supply to the lower leg.
subject: Anatomy

question_text: The hunter's canal lies beneath which muscle?
explanation:
The hunter’s canal lies beneath the sartorius muscle. It is also referred to as the subsartorial canal or adductor canal.
The hunter’s canal is a triangular intermuscular tunnel occupying the lower two-thirds of the medial aspect of the thigh.
subject: Anatomy

question_text: A 40 year old basketball player who sustained an ACL tear is being posted for ACL reconstruction surgery. The anesthetist plans an adductor canal block for the procedure. Which of the following structures is he least likely to encounter while giving the block ?
explanation:
The femoral nerve is least likely to be encountered while giving an adductor canal block. Adductor canal does not contain the femoral nerve. However, it contains its branches - the saphenous and and nerve to vastus medialis.
Contents of the adductor canal:
Saphenous nerve (largest cutaneous branch of the femoral nerve)
Nerve to vastus medialis
Femoral artery
Descending genicular artery
Femoral vein
Deep lymphatic vessels
subject: Anatomy

question_text: Which of the following is the correct relationship with regards to the saphenous nerve in the adductor canal?
explanation: The saphenous nerve is anterior to the femoral artery in the adductor canal.
subject: Anatomy

question_text: A patient presents with a chronic ulcer in the popliteal fossa. The surgeon plans to make a musculocutaneous flap using a muscle from the superolateral boundary of the fossa. Which muscle is to be used for the flap?
explanation:
The surgeon plans to use the biceps femoris muscle for the flap. Biceps femoris forms the superolateral border of the popliteal fossa.
Popliteal fossa is a diamond-shaped region present posterior to the knee.
subject: Anatomy

question_text: Which of the following is not a content of the popliteal fossa?
explanation:
The lateral femoral cutaneous nerve is not a content of the popliteal fossa. It arises from the ventral rami of L2 and L3, and ends up supplying the skin of anterolateral thigh.
Contents of Popliteal fossa:
Popliteal artery and its branches
Popliteal vein and its tributaries
Tibial nerve
Common fibular (Peroneal) nerve
Short saphenous vein
Posterior femoral cutaneous nerve
Articular branch of the obturator nerve
Medial and Lateral sural cutaneous nerve
Lymph nodes
Fat
Bursae
subject: Anatomy

question_text: Which of the following bones form the anterior pillar of the lateral longitudinal arch of the foot?
options: Talus, navicular, 3 cuneiform and 1st, 2nd and 3rd metatarsa
explanation: The anterior pillar of the lateral longitudinal arch of the foot is formed by 4th and 5th metatarsals.
subject: Anatomy

question_text: The keystone of the medial longitudinal arch is formed by 	.
explanation: The keystone (summit) of the medial longitudinal arch is formed by the talus.
subject: Anatomy

question_text: A 42-year-old man had trauma to the right foot, following which he complained of difficulty in walking. Examination showed collapse of the medial longitudinal arch. Injury to all of the following structures may cause the given condition except:
explanation:
Peroneus longus muscle maintains the lateral longitudinal arch and not the medial arch.
The muscles, tendons, and aponeurosis that maintain the longitudinal arches of the foot are of two types:
Slings: These structures help to maintain the arch by suspending the arch from above.
Tie beams (bowstrings): These are present between the anterior and posterior pillars and help maintain the arch by preventing the separation of the pillars.
subject: Anatomy

question_text: Which of the following structures does not pass deep to the superior extensor retinacula of foot?
explanation:
The tendon of tibialis posterior does not pass deep to the superior extensor retinacula of the foot. The following are the structures passing deep to the superior and inferior extensor retinacula:
Tibialis anterior tendon
Extensor hallucis longus tendon
Deep peroneal nerve
Extensor digitorum longus tendon
Peroneus tertius tendon
The anterior tibial vessels pass deep to the superior extensor retinaculum, while the dorsalis pedis vessels pass deep to the inferior extensor retinaculum.
Note: The tendon of tibialis posterior passes deep to the flexor retinaculum of the foot
subject: Anatomy

question_text: Which of the following statements is false about the inferior extensor retinaculum of the foot?
options: The upper band is attached to the lower end of the fibula
The lower band is attached to the deep fascia of sole
Laterally it is attached to calcaneum
explanation:
Upper band is attached to medial malleolus of the tibia and not fibula. Inferior extensor retinaculum:
It is a Y-shaped band lying anterior to the ankle joint.
The stem of the Y is at the lateral end and is attached to the upper surface of the calcaneus.
The limbs of the Y are at the medial end. The proximal limb attaches to the medial malleolus and the distal limb blends with the plantar aponeurosis.
Structures passing deep to retinaculum are:
Peroneus tertius
Extensor digitorum longus
Extensor hallucis longus
Tibialis anterior
Anterior tibial vessels
Dorsalis pedis artery
Deep peroneal nerve
subject: Anatomy

question_text:
Which of the following is the most medial structure passing through the canals in the flexor retinaculum of the foot?
Flexor digitorum longus tendon
explanation:
Tibialis posterior tendon is the most medial structure passing through the canals in the flexor retinaculum of the foot.
The flexor retinaculum of the foot converts grooves on the tibia and calcaneus into canals for the tendons. The structures passing through canals formed by flexor retinaculum are as follows: (from medial to lateral)
Tendons of tibialis posterior
Flexor digitorum longus
The posterior tibial vessels
The tibial nerve
The tendon of flexor hallucis longus
Vertebral Column
subject: Anatomy

question_text: Which of the following is a characteristic difference between a typical cervical and thoracic vertebra?
options: Cervical vertebrae have longer spinous processes
Thoracic vertebrae foramina are bigger than the body
Thoracic vertebrae have turbercles on transverse processes
explanation:
The typical cervical vertebrae are characterized by a foramen in the transverse process called the foramen transversarium.
This foramen transversarium transmits the vertebral artery and vein, along with a branch from the cervicothoracic ganglion (vertebral nerve). Lateral parts of the transverse processes of the cervical vertebrae also contain the anterior and posterior tubercles.
The images given below illustrate a typical cervical and thoracic vertebrae respectively.
subject: Anatomy

question_text: What is the number of bones in the vertebral column?
explanation:
The vertebral column consists of 33 bones. Generally, the number of vertebrae found in each segment are as follows:
7 cervica
12 thoracic
5 lumbar
5 sacra
4 coccygea
However, this total is subject to frequent variability, and there have been reports of variation between 32 and 35 vertebrae.
The total length of vertebral column is about 70 cm in males and about 60 cm in females on an average. Fibrocartilaginous intervertebral discs separate neighboring vertebrae in the cervical, thoracic and lumbar region (except the first 2 cervical vertebrae). The vertebral column supports the trunk, protects the spinal cord and nerves, and provide attachments for muscles. It is also an important site of hematopoiesis throughout life.
The image given below illustrates the adult vertebral column.
subject: Anatomy

question_text: Which of the following pairs of 'vertebral segment-normal curvature' is incorrectly matched?
explanation:
The cervical-kyphosis pair is incorrectly matched. The cervical part of the vertebral column normally demonstrates lordosis.
During embryonic life, the body appears flexed and has 2 primary spinal curvatures. These are the thoracic and the pelvic curves, which are convex dorsally. After birth, functional muscle development leads to the early appearance of secondary spinal curvatures. These are the cervica and the lumbar curves, both of which are convex forwards (lordosis).
Normal adult curvatures of the vertebral column are as follows:
The cervical curve is lordosis (convex forwards)
The thoracic curve is kyphosis (convex dorsally)
The lumbar curve is lordosis (convex forwards)
The pelvic curve is concave anteroinferiorly
The image given below illustrates the adult vertebral column.
subject: Anatomy

question_text: Which statement regarding normal vertebral column curvature is false?
options: Thoracic curve develops when the infant starts walking.
Cervical curve appears when the infant starts supporting its head.
Lumbar curve appears when the child assumes the upright posture.
explanation:
The thoracic curvature is a primary curve and is developed during embryonic life itself.
Both the primary curves (thoracic and pelvic) that appear during embryonic life are convex dorsally. After birth, functional muscle development results in the appearance of secondary cervical and lumbar spinal curvatures in the sagittal plane.
The secondary cervical curvature occurs with the development of function in the muscles responsible for the head extension.
The secondary lumbar curvature occurs with the development of function in the muscles responsible for sitting upright and walking.
subject: Anatomy

question_text: A 32-year-old man suffered from iatrogenic trauma of the craniovertebral joint following occipitocervical fusion and stabilization surgery. Which of the following structures are not included in this joint?
explanation:
The craniovertebral joints do not include the wings of the sphenoid. These connect the cranium to the vertebral column.
They include the atlanto-occipital joints and atlanto-axial joints.
The bones involved include the occipital condyles, the atlas, and the axis.
These joints are specialized to provide greater mobility than seen in the rest of the axial skeleton. Together, they function as a universal joint that allows horizontal and vertical scanning movements of the head.
Occipitocervical fusion and stabilization surgery is the treatment of choice for patients with occipitocervical pathologies including trauma, rheumatoid arthritis, congenital malformations, neoplasms, and degeneration. High degree of mobility and the sharp angle at which the occiput meets the upper cervical spine, makes rigid surgical fixation challenging.
subject: Anatomy

question_text: The movements at the 	 joint permit a person to look to the right and left.
explanation:
The movements at the atlanto-axial joint allow a person to look left and right. The atlanto-axial joints include 3 synovial joints:
Median atlanto-axial joint- The central pivot joint between the dens of the axis and a ring formed by the anterior arch and transverse atlantal ligament
Lateral atlanto-axial joints- Plain synovial joints between lateral masses of atlas and upper facets of the body of axis
Movements at the atlanto-axial joint almost exclusively is rotation around the axis, which help side-to-side rotation of the head. The normal range of atlanto-axial rotation is about 40°.
subject: Anatomy

question_text: An orthopedician performing surgical decompression in a patient with cervical spondylosis accidentally damages the transverse atlantal ligament. What is this a component of?
explanation:
The transverse atlantal ligament is a component of the cruciform ligaments at the atlanto-axial joints.
Cruciform ligaments are shaped like a cross:
The horizontal component of the cross is formed by the transverse atlantal ligament. It is attached on each side to the lateral mass of atlas. It retains the dens in position.
The vertical component of the cross is formed by the superior and inferior longitudina ligaments.
Superior longitudinal ligament arises from the upper margin of the transverse atlantal ligament and inserts into the basilar part of the occipital bone.
Inferior longitudinal ligament arises from the lower margin of the transverse atlantal ligament and inserts to the posterior surface of the axis vertebra.
Other ligaments at the atlanto-axial joints:
Membrana tectoria- Strong band found inside the vertebral canal, which is the upward continuation of the posterior longitudinal ligament
Alar ligaments- Thick cords from the apex of the dens to the medial side of the occipital condyles
Apical ligament of the dens- Connects the apex of dens to the anterior margin of the foramen magnum between the alar ligaments
subject: Anatomy

question_text: A 44-year-old man is brought to the casualty with a suspected whiplash injury following a road traffic accident. Which ligament would be injured in this condition?
explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of a whiplash injury. In this, the anterior longitudinal ligament of the spine is damaged.
Whiplash is a form of cervical acceleration-deceleration injury. There is hyperextension followed by flexion in the recoil. The main pathological features seen in these cases include tear
(strain) of the anterior longitudinal ligament and the capsular fibers of the facet joints in the spine. In some cases, the intervertebral discs may be damaged. Fracture is seen in severe cases only.
Anterior longitudinal ligament:
It is a strong band that extends along the anterior surface of the vertebral bodies
It extends from the basilar part of the occipital bone to the upper sacrum
It is attached to the anterior tubercle of C1 and the body of C2
subject: Anatomy

question_text: MRI of a 54-year-old woman with rheumatoid arthritis showed tectorial membrane thickening. This structure is derived from which of the following ligaments?
explanation:
Membrana tectoria or tectorial membrane is the cranial continuation of the posterior longitudinal ligament.
The posterior longitudinal ligament is present in the vertebral canal on the posterior surfaces of the vertebral bodies. The posterior longitudinal ligaments stretch from the body of the axis (C2) to the sacrum.
Above the level of axis, the posterior longitudinal ligament continues as membrana tectoria. Membrana tectoria extends from the axis to the foramen magnum.
subject: Anatomy

question_text: A 75-year-old cachexic man presents with nagging back pain in the lumbar region that shoots down his right leg. He was diagnosed with prostate cancer 2 months back. Which of the following movements is anatomically restricted in the lumbar region?
explanation:
Rotation is anatomically restricted in the lumbar region.
The given clinical vignette is suggestive of carcinoma prostate, which has metastasised to the lumbar spine. Anatomically, the lumbar region of the vertebral column has a restricted range for rotational movements.
Movements of the vertebral column:
Flexion of the spine is accompanied by relaxation of the anterior longitudinal ligament and compression of the anterior parts of the intervertebral discs. Flexion is effectively absent in the thoracic region. Flexion movements are greater than extension or lateral flexion in the lumbar region.
Extension is marked in cervical and lumbar regions. It is significantly less at thoracic levels as their discs are thinner and because of the ribs and chest musculature.
Lateral flexion is flexion combined with coupled axial rotation. Lateral movements occur in a parts of the column but are the greatest in the cervical and lumbar regions.
Axial rotation is the highest in the cervical region, 50% of which occurs at the atlantoaxial joint. All the other spine segments below the cervical have only a slight range of rotation, among which the thoracolumbar junction has the most. The remainder of the lumbar region has very little rotation.
subject: Anatomy

question_text: An army personnel complains of lower backache following a bullet wound. On examination, she has sensory loss on the ipsilateral side below the level of the lesion. What is false about the visceral landmarks of the affected structure?
options: Heart lies in T5-T8 in recumbent position.
SVC enters right atrium at T5.
Azygous vein enters SVC at T5.
Hemiazygous vein crosses left to right at T5.
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Brown-Sequard syndrome caused due to injury to the vertebral column by a bullet wound. The hemiazygous vein crosses from left to right at the level of the T8 vertebra (and not T5).
subject: Anatomy

question_text: The following procedure was planned for a patient with a suspicion of Guillain-Barré syndrome. What is not pierced during this procedure?
explanation:
A lumbar puncture is planned for this patient with a suspicion of Guillain-Barré syndrome. The posterior longitudinal ligament is not pierced during lumbar puncture.
Structures pierced during lumbar puncture (in that order):
Skin
Subcutaneous tissue
Supraspinous ligament
Interspinous ligament
Ligamentum flavum
Epidural space
Dura mater
Arachnoid mater
subject: Anatomy

question_text: You are asked to auscultate a patient presenting with chronic cough. Which of the following is not a boundary of the triangle of auscultation?
explanation:
The serratus anterior is not a boundary of the triangle of auscultation. As there are fewer impedances between the examiner's stethoscope and the lungs, this area allows for better auscultation of the patient.
Boundaries of the triangle of auscultation:
Medially- trapezius muscle’s lateral border
Laterally- scapula’s medial border
Inferiorly- lattssisimus dorsi’s upper border
Floor- 5th and 7th rib, 6th intercostal space, and the rhomboid major
The triangle overlies the inferior lobe of both lungs. For exposure of the floor of the triangle, the patient needs to fold their arm across their chest to rotate the scapula laterally and bend forward resembling somewhat a fetal position.
The image given below illustrates the triangle of auscultation.
subject: Anatomy

question_text:
The muscle marked by the arrow in the image below is innervated by the	.
Dorsal scapular nerve
options: From the dorsal rami of C1
explanation:
The muscle marked in the above image is levator scapulae, which is innervated by the dorsal scapular nerve.
The appendicular group of back muscles and their innervations include:
Option B: The suprascapular nerve innervates the supraspinatus and infraspinatus muscles. Option D: The subscapular nerves supply the teres major and subscapularis muscles.
Bones, Joints and Cartilage
subject: Anatomy

question_text: The total number of bones present in the axial skeleton and appendicular skeleton in an adult human being is 	 and 	, respectively.
explanation: In the adult, 80 bones are present in the axial skeleton, and 126 bones in the appendicular skeleton.
subject: Anatomy

question_text: Which of the following statements regarding bones is false?
options: Osteocytes are the major cell type in mature bone
Collagen is synthesized in bone by osteoblasts
Bone mainly contains type 2 collagen fibres
Calcium phosphate is the major inorganic mineral
explanation:
Bone mainly contains type 1 collagen fibres. Bones are made up of mineralized collagenous extracellular matrix around specialized cells.
The extracellular matrix is composed of:
Organic component - around 30% of the organic matrix of bone is made up of collagen, mainly type 1 collagen.
Inorganic component - the major inorganic mineral in the bone matrix is calcium phosphate in the form of microcrystalline hydroxyapatite.
The specialized cells are:
Osteoblasts - responsible for the synthesis, deposition, and mineralization of the bone
matrix. Collagen is synthesized in bone by osteoblasts. Osteoblasts get embedded in the matrix to become osteocytes.
Osteocytes - major cell type of a mature bone and is distributed throughout the matrix. They have lost the ability to divide or to secrete new matrix.
Osteoclasts - responsible for the local removal of bone during bone growth and remodelling.
subject: Anatomy

question_text: Which of the following is a modified long bone?
explanation:
The clavicle is a modified long bone, as it has a modified shaft and no medullary cavity. Long bones are classified as follows:
Typical long bones (see figure) have an elongated shaft (diaphysis) and two expanded ends (epiphysis). The shaft has a central medullary cavity and a nutrient foramen directed away from the growing end. e.g., humerus, ulna, radius, femur, tibia, and fibula.
Miniature long bones contain only one epiphysis. e.g., metacarpals, metatarsals, and phalanges.
Modified long bones have a modified shaft or ends, and no medullary cavity. e.g., clavicle. The following image shows a graphical illustration of a typical long bone:
subject: Anatomy

question_text: Which of the following is not a sesamoid bone?
explanation:
Os trigonum is an accessory bone, not a sesamoid bone.
Accessory bones, also known as supernumerary bones are not always present. They may arise due to ununited epiphysis developed from extra ossification centres. Clinically, they may be mistaken for fractures.
Examples of accessory bones:
Os trigonum - Uncommon accessory bone seen behind the talus. Also known as lateral tubercle of the talus.
Os vesalianum - Uncommon accessory bone located proximal to the fifth metatarsal and found within the peroneus brevis tendon. Also known as tuberosity of the fifth metatarsal.
subject: Anatomy

question_text: Which of the following is an example of a ■pneumatic bone?
explanation:
The maxilla is a pneumatic bone.
Pneumatic bones contain air-filled cavities, which make them light-weight. They also aid in the resonance of sound and act as air conditioning chambers for inspired air. e.g., maxilla, sphenoid, ethmoid, etc.
Short bones: Carpal bones and tarsal bones
Flat bones: Sternum, ribs, scapula, and bones of the skull vault Irregular bones: Hip bones, vertebra, and bones in the base of the skull.
subject: Anatomy

question_text: Which of the following accurately describes fabella?
explanation:
Fabella is a sesamoid bone. This term is used to describe a bone embedded within a tendon or a muscle. It is a variant of normal anatomy present in 10% to 30% of individuals. Fabella is found within the tendon of the lateral head of gastrocnemius, where it moves over the lateral femoral condyle.
Important sesamoid bones:
Patella - largest sesamoid bone in the tendon of quadriceps femoris.
Pisiform - tendon of flexor carpi ulnaris.
Fabella - lateral head of the gastrocnemius.
Two sesamoid bones can be found in the first metacarpal within the tendons of flexor pollicis brevis and adductor pollicis.
Two sesamoid bones can be found in the first metatarsophalangeal articulation within the double tendon of flexor hallucis brevis.
The X-ray image below depicts the fabella (marked with an arrow).
subject: Anatomy

question_text: Which of the following statements is true regarding long bones?
options: Cancellous bone is absent in the epiphysis
Cancellous bone is present in the outer cortex
Haversian system is absent in cancellous bone
Compact bone has lamellae arranged in a meshwork
explanation:
The Haversian system is seen in compact bones, not cancellous bones.
Based on their macroscopic structure, bones can be classified as compact and cancellous (spongy)
bones.
Compact bones are composed of cylindrical structural units called Haversian systems or osteons. Each Haversian system contains a central canal within which the small blood vessels,
nerves, and endosteum are present. This canal is surrounded by multiple layers or lamellae of the calcified matrix containing type I collagen fibers. These canals communicate with each other by Volkmann's canal.
The lamellae of the cancellous/spongy bone are arranged in a meshwork, and hence do not form Haversian systems.
The diaphysis and outer cortex of long bones are predominantly made of compact bone, while the epiphysis and inner medulla are predominantly made of cancellous bone.
subject: Anatomy

question_text: A 16-year-old boy presented to your OPD with progressive swelling and worsening knee pain over the past 2 months. An X-ray reveals the following finding. Which of the following is true regarding the layer of bone involved?
options: Progenitor cells are present in the outer fibrous layer
It is continuous with the capsule of the joint
It is devoid of nerve supply
explanation:
The given X-ray shows Codman's triangle, which is due to an irregular periosteal reaction (outermost layer), commonly seen in patients with osteosarcoma. The periosteum is a thick fibrous membrane that covers the outer surface of all bones, except at the joint surfaces and insertion points of tendons and ligaments (entheses). At the articular margin, the periosteum is continuous with the capsule of the joint.
The periosteum has 2 layers:
The outer fibrous layer - contains fibroblasts.
The inner cambium layer (osteogenic layer) - contains progenitor cells that develop into osteoblasts.
Periosteum gets nourishment from periosteal arteries. It has a rich nerve supply, which makes it the most sensitive part of the bone.
subject: Anatomy

question_text: Which of the following structures do the Sharpey's fibers connect?
explanation:
Sharpey's fibers are thick collagen fibers that connect the periosteum to the underlying bone. Sharpey's fibers are present in the bone and the teeth.
Bone - tether the periosteum to the underlying bone.
Teeth - connect the cementum to the periosteum of the alveolar bone (tooth socket).
subject: Anatomy

question_text: Which of the following bones develops through intramembranous ossification?
explanation:
Frontal bones undergo intramembranous ossification. Other bones listed have enchondral ossification.
Based on their development, bones can be classified into 3 categories:
Membranous bones (dermal bones) are formed through intramembranous ossification. There is direct bone formation within highly vascular sheets or ‘membranes’ derived from mesenchymal condensations. e.g., bones of the facial skeleton including the frontal, lacrimal, zygomatic, and nasal bones.
Cartilaginous bones are formed by intra-cartilaginous (enchondral) ossification. Bone forms by ossification of preformed hyaline cartilage model. This is the main method of bone formation in the body. e.g., bones of limbs, vertebral column, and thoracic cage.
Membranocartilaginous bones ossify from both cartilage and mesenchymal condensation. e.g., clavicle, mandible, occipital bone, temporal bone, sphenoid bone, etc.
subject: Anatomy

question_text: The structure that the marked muscle in the gluteal region inserts into has 	 type of epiphysis?
explanation:
The muscle marked in the image is the piriformis and its insertion is at the greater trochanter of the femur, which is an example of traction epiphysis.
Traction epiphysis is nonarticular and does not transmit weight. They provide attachment to one or more tendons that exert traction on the epiphysis. Examples of traction epiphysis include greater and lesser tubercles of the humerus and greater and lesser trochanters of the femur.
subject: Anatomy

question_text: While assessing a child with short stature, the senior resident orders an X-ray to better evaluate the structure marked X in the radiograph. Which of the following is a true statement regarding this structure?
options: It is made of elastic cartilage
It is supplied only by epiphyseal arteries
It is the site for enchondral ossification
explanation:
The structure marked X in the radiograph is the epiphyseal plate. It is the site for enchondral ossification that is mainly responsible for the growth of long bones.
The epiphyseal plate (growth plate) is a hyaline cartilage layer that separates the epiphysis from the metaphysis. It receives nourishment from both the epiphyseal and metaphyseal
arteries. Fractures involving epiphyseal plates are known as Salter-Harris fractures. The growing ends of bones include:
Upper limb: Upper end of humerus, and lower ends of radius and ulna
Lower limb: Lower end of femur, and upper end of tibia
subject: Anatomy

question_text: 'The secondary ossification center that appears first, fuses last'. Which of the following bones violates this law?
explanation:
The fibula violates the law of ossification which states that the secondary ossification center that appears first is the last to fuse.
The secondary ossification center at the lower end of the fibula appears before the ossification center of the upper end and fuses before the upper end.
Ossification centers are of two types:
Primary centers appear before birth, usually during late embryonic or early fetal life (seventh week to the fourth month). They form the diaphysis.
Secondary centers usually appear after birth. They form the epiphysis.
subject: Anatomy

question_text: Which of the following parts of the bone is not nourished by the nutrient artery?
explanation:
The nutrient artery does not nourish the outer one-third of the cortex.
The nutrient artery enters the bone shaft through the nutrient foramen and runs obliquely through the cortex.
N trient arteries of the long bones are directed away from the dominant growing epiphysis as the growing bone might pull and rupture the artery. So the nutrient foramina are directed away from the growing end. The direction of the nutrient artery can be remembered by the axiom 'To the elbow, I go, from the knee I flee'.
subject: Anatomy

question_text: In which of the following parts of the bone are hairpin bends of end arteries abundantly present?
explanation:
Hairpin bends of end arteries are seen abundantly in the metaphysis.
The metaphysis is the portion of a long bone between the epiphysis and diaphysis. It is the zone of active growth and is highly vascular. Before epiphysial fusion, the metaphysis is richly supplied through end arteries that form 'hairpin' bends.
The metaphysis is the most common location for osteomyelitis in children because the bacteria or emboli are easily trapped in the hairpin bends, thereby causing infection.
subject: Anatomy

question_text: Which of the following statements regarding cartilage is false?
explanation:
Articular cartilage despite being a type of hyaline cartilage lacks perichondrium.
Cartilage is a connective tissue composed of cells (chondrocytes) and fibers (collagen or yellow elastic fibers). These are embedded in a firm, gel-like matrix that is rich in mucopolysaccharides. It is much more elastic than bone. Cartilage does not have blood vessels or lymphatics.
Chondrocytes get their nutrition by diffusion. Cartilage has no nerves and is insensitive. There are three types of cartilages:
Hyaline cartilage
Elastic cartilage
Fibrocartilage
Hyaline cartilage (except the subtype of articular cartilage) and elastic cartilage have perichondrium. Fibrocartilage does not have perichondrium.
subject: Anatomy

question_text: Which of the following does not have yellow cartilage?
explanation:
The septal nasal cartilage has hyaline cartilage and not yellow (elastic) cartilage.
Elastic cartilage (or yellow cartilage) contains a matrix rich in fine yellow elastic fibers containing the protein elastin. It is present in:
Apices of arytenoid
Epiglottis
Corniculate cartilages
Cuneiform cartilages
Eustachian tube
Pinna (Auricle)
External auditory meatus
subject: Anatomy

question_text: What is the type of cartilage found in the structure marked X in the following radiograph?
explanation:
The structure marked X is the pubic symphysis and the type of cartilage seen is fibrocartilage.
Fibrocartilage contains a mixture of white fibrous tissue and cartilaginous tissue. This mix of fibrous and cartilaginous components make this tissue extremely tough and
resilient. Fibrocartilage is present in the following sites:
Pubic symphysis
Manubriosternal joint
Articular discs of temporomandibular and sternoclavicular joints
Anulus fibrosus of intervertebral discs
Menisci of the knee
Acetabular labrum
Glenoid labrum
The lining of bony grooves for tendons
subject: Anatomy

question_text: In which of the following cartilages is type I collagen predominantly seen?
explanation: Fibrocartilage predominantly contains type I collagen. Hyaline and elastic cartilages mainly contain type II collagen.
subject: Anatomy

question_text: Ligamentum flavum has high levels of:
explanation:
Ligamentum flavum has high levels of elastin fibres.
The ligamenta flava are a series of ligaments that connect the ventral parts of the laminae of adjacent vertebrae. They predominantly contain elastic tissue and form part of the posterior surface of the vertebral canal. The high content of elastin allows it to be stretched by 80% without damage. The ligamentum flava resist separation of the laminae in flexion and assist in extension back to the anatomical position.
subject: Anatomy

question_text: Which of the following is not a fibrous joint?
explanation: The symphysis is not a fibrous joint, but a secondary cartilaginous joint. Structural classification of joints is as follows:
subject: Anatomy

question_text: What are synovial joints functionally classified as?
explanation:
Synovial joints are freely movable joints and therefore functionally classified as diarthrosis. Functional classification of joints:
Synarthroses - These are immovable. e.g., fibrous joints
Amphiarthroses - They are slightly mobile. e.g., cartilaginous joints
Diarthroses - These are freely mobile. e.g., synovial joints.
subject: Anatomy

question_text: Which of the following accurately describes a joint with three or more articular surfaces?
explanation:
A joint with three or more articular surfaces is classified as a compound joint. Classification of joints based on the number of articulating surfaces:
Simple joints have 2 articulation surfaces. e.g., shoulder joint, hip joint.
Compound joints have 3 or more articulation surfaces. e.g., elbow joint, wrist joint.
Complex joints have an intra-articular disc between the articular surfaces which divides the joint space. e.g., temporomandibular joint, sternoclavicular joint.
subject: Anatomy

question_text: Which of the following joints is known as a peg-and-socket joint?
explanation:
Gomphosis (dentoalveolar syndesmosis) is a peg-and-socket joint between a tooth and its socket.
Fibrous joints are joints where bones are joined together by fibrous tissue. They are further classified as sutures, syndesmosis, and gomphosis (see Table).
The following image shows the types of fibrous joints:
subject: Anatomy

question_text: What type of joint is an incudostapedial joint?
explanation:
The incudostapedial joint is a ball and socket type of joint.
In ball and socket type of joints, the articular surfaces include a globular head (male surface) fitting into a cup-shaped socket (female surface). These joints are multi-axial and movements occur around a number of axes. Flexion, extension, abduction, adduction, medial rotation, lateral rotation, and circumduction, all occur quite freely. E.g., shoulder joint, hip joint,
talocalcaneonavicular joint, and incudostapedial joint.
Note: The other joint between the incus and malleus (incudomalleolar joint) is a saddle joint.
subject: Anatomy

question_text: A 47-year-old lady diagnosed with rheumatoid arthritis presented to the clinic with the following deformity. The joint involved in this condition is an example of
explanation:
The deformity shown is hallux valgus. This is caused due to an excessive lateral deviation at the first metatarsophalangeal joint. It is an example of an ellipsoid joint.
Ellipsoid joints have an oval, convex (male) surface fitting into an elliptical concave (female) surface. They show biaxial movements such as flexion-extension, and abduction–adduction. A combination of these movements results in circumduction. Movement on the third axis is prevented due to the general articular shape.
E.g., Wrist (radiocarpal) joint, atlanto-occipital joints, metacarpophalangeal joints, and metatarsophalangeal joints.
subject: Anatomy

question_text: The talocalcaneonavicular joint is a 	type of joint.
explanation:
The talocalcaneonavicular joint is a ball and socket joint.
The ball part is formed by the rounded head of the talus.
The socket is formed by 3 structures:
Posterior surface of the navicular
Anterior articular surface of the calcaneus
Upper surface of the plantar calcaneonavicular ligament (spring ligament).
subject: Anatomy

question_text: Forward and backward movements of the mandible that occur at the temporomandibular joint is called as	and 	, respectively.
explanation:
Forward and backward movement of the mandible that occurs at the temporomandibular joints are called as protraction and retraction, respectively. Protraction occurs when the lower jaw is pushed forward, while retraction pulls the lower jaw backward.
Protraction and retraction also occur in the scapula. During protraction, the scapula is moved laterally and anteriorly along the chest wall, such as during rowing movements. Retraction is bringing scapula back to the original position after protraction.
Option A: Opposition is the thumb movement that brings the tip of the thumb in contact with the tip of a finger. Returning the thumb to its anatomical position next to the index finger is called reposition.
Option B: Excursion is the side to side movement of the mandible.
Option D: Depression and elevation are downward and upward movements of the mandible (or scapula), respectively.
subject: Anatomy

question_text: All of the following are rounded or irregular elevations of bones, except
explanation:
The styloid process is a sharp elevation of bone. Bony elevations can be sharp or rounded:
Rounded or irregular elevations include a tubercle, tuberosity, epicondyle, malleolus, and trochanter.
Sharp elevations of bones include styloid process, spine, cornu (horn), and hamulus (hook-like).
subject: Anatomy

question_text:
The type of joint marked in the image below is 	:
Syndesmosis
explanation:
The joint marked in the above image is the costotransverse joint, which is a synovial type of joint. The various types of joints in the thoracic wall include:
Sternocostal joints: These are the joints between the costal cartilages of the first seven ribs and the sternum.
The joint between the 1st costal cartilage and manubrium is a fibrocartilaginous joint
(synarthrosis).
The joints between the 2nd to 7th costal cartilages and the sternum are synovial joints.
The interchondral joint between the costal cartilages of the 9th and 10th ribs is never synovial and is usually absent.
Muscles and Tendons
subject: Anatomy

question_text: Which of the following statements is true regarding muscles in general?
options: Origin of muscle moves during contraction
Insertion of muscle is fixed during contraction
Origin and insertion of muscle is fixed during contraction
Origin of muscle is fixed during contraction
explanation:
The origin of the muscle is fixed, while the insertion moves during contraction.
Skeletal muscles exert their force on the bones through their tendon attachments and the force generated helps in generating movements or in maintaining posture.
subject: Anatomy

question_text: Which of the following statements about muscles is false?
options: Smooth muscles and cardiac muscles are bounded by plasmalemma
Intercalated discs are absent in skeletal muscles and smooth muscles
Skeletal muscle and smooth muscle fibres are multi-nucleated
Smooth muscles and cardiac muscles are supplied by autonomic nervous system
explanation:
Skeletal muscles are multinucleated, while smooth muscles are uninucleated. There are three major muscle types in the human body:
Skeletal muscle
Smooth muscle
Cardiac muscle
subject: Anatomy

question_text: Which of the following is a true statement regarding skeletal muscle?
options: Muscle groups are surrounded by endomysium
Muscle fibers are surrounded by endomysium
Muscle groups are surrounded by perimysium
Muscle fibers are surrounded by perimysium
explanation:
The muscle fibres are surrounded by a delicate network of connective tissue called the endomysium.
Muscles are supported by connective tissue in various layers namely:
Endomysium - surrounds individual muscle fibers.
Perimysium - surrounds a bundle of muscle fibers (fasciculi).
Epimysium - surrounds whole muscle or muscle groups.
The endomysial, perimysial and epimysial layers fuse at locations where the muscles connect to adjacent structures such as tendons, aponeuroses, and fasciae.
subject: Anatomy

question_text: Which of the following muscles does not predominantly contain oblique fasciculi?
explanation:
The rectus abdominis muscle contains parallel fasciculi. The other muscles listed have oblique fasciculi.
Muscles can be classified based on the arrangement of muscle fibers relative to the direction of pull as follows:
Parallel - muscle fasciculi are parallel to the line of pull.
Oblique - muscle fasciculi are oblique to the line of pull.
Spiral - muscle fasciculi have a spiral or twisted arrangement.
Parallel muscles can be further grouped based on their shape as follows:
Quadrilateral - parallel fibers run for a short distance.
Strap-like - parallel fibers run for a long distance.
Strap-like with tendinous intersections - parallel fibers are interrupted by tendinous insertions.
Fusiform - parallel fibers in the muscle belly that converge at the tendon region.
subject: Anatomy

question_text: Which of the following accurately describes the shape of trapezius muscle?
explanation:
The trapezius muscle individually is a flat, triangular muscle that extends over the back of the neck and upper thorax. When paired together, they resemble a trapezium and hence the name.
Muscles with oblique fibers are further subclassified as follows:
Triangular - They are triangular in shape.
Pennate - They are feather-shaped. Based on their complexity, they can have the following subtypes:
Unipennate - fascicles on one side of the tendon.
Bipennate - fascicles on two sides of the tendon.
Multipennate - central tendon branches into two or more branches within the muscle.
Circumpennate (radial) - muscle fibers converge to a central tendon in a radial fashion.
subject: Anatomy

question_text: Identify the type of muscle marked as X in the image below.
explanation:
The muscle marked X in the cadaveric image is the pectoralis major, which is a spiral muscle. Spiral muscles have fiber architecture as follows:
The muscle fibers have a spiral or twisted arrangement. e.g., pectoralis major (sternocosta fibers) and latissimus dorsi that undergo a 180° twist between their medial and latera attachments.
The entire muscle takes a spiral course around a bone. e.g., supinator winds obliquely around the proximal radial shaft.
Cruciate is a type of spiral muscle where two or more planes of muscle fibers are arranged in differing directions. e.g., sternocleidomastoid, masseter and adductor magnus are all partially spiral and cruciate.
subject: Anatomy

question_text: Which of the following muscles do not have parallel oriented muscle fibers?
explanation:
